title: Dow hits 6-week high as stocks rally amid earnings deluge while Treasury yields retreat
text:
* The Dow DJIA rose 284 points, or 0.9%, to 31,784.

* The S&P 500 SPX was up 52 points, or 1.4%, at 3,849.

* The Nasdaq Composite COMP gained 213 points, or 2%, to trade at 11,166.

The S&P 500 has climbed during four of the last six trading days and ended Monday at its highest level since Sept. 20.

What's driving markets

Stocks continued to build on their recent gains Tuesday as all three major U.S. indexes rose to notable new highs, with the S&P 500 trading at its highest level intraday since Sept. 21, while the Nasdaq traded at its highest level since Oct. 6, according to FactSet data.

Investors were weighing results from Dow components Coca-Cola Co. KO and 3M Co. MMM, as well as General Electric Co. GE. After the close, earnings are due from Google parent Alphabet Inc. GOOGL and Microsoft Corp. MSFT.

See: Big Tech has been an earnings refuge for years, but safety is no longer a sure thing

Treasury yields are continuing to drive trading in tocks, Only now, a pullback in yields is helping to lift stocks.

"We're seeing yields come down for the first time in a while, so stocks are going up," said Art Hogan, chief market strategist at B.Reily Wealth.

The drop in yields is largely a factor of the Federal Reserve's messaging about slowing the pace of interest rate hikes after its November meeting, which the central bank unveiled last week in what some analysts viewed as a coordinated fashion as a story published in The Wall Street Journal said policy makers would debate the size of a December rate riske, while comments by San Francisco President Mary Daly called for the Fed to eventually slow down.

The yield on the 10-year Treasury note BX:TMUBMUSD10Y was down 12 basis points at 4.107%. Yields move inversely to prices.

From a technical standpoint, market strategists expect the rally in stocks may have more room to run now that the S&P 500 has surmounted strong resistance at the 3,800 level, clearing the way for the large-cap index to rise past 3,900, Hogan said.

See: Stocks are having a stellar October. Why the bear-market rally may have more room to run.

Meanwhile, corporate earnings in the U.S. have continued to surpass analysts' diminished expectations, adding another tailwind to equity valuations.

In aggregate, companies are reporting earnings growth at 5.8% above expectations, compared with an average of 7.0% for the prior four quarters, according to Refinitiv.

All 11 S&P 500 sectors were trading in the green on Tuesday, with the S&P 500 real-estate sector putting in the best performance among its peers with a 3.4% gain as the pullback in Treasury yields will remove some of the pressure driving up mortgage rates.

On the economic data front, the Conference Board said its U.S. consumer confidence index fell to 102.5 in October from 107.8 a month earlier.

The S&P CoreLogic Case-Shiller 20-city house-price index fell 1.3% in August, its second consecutive monthly decline.

Companies in focus

* Coca-Cola shares rose 0.7% after the beverage giant beat third-quarter profit and revenue expectations, as price increases helped offset ongoing cost inflation.

* 3M Co. shares fell 0.5% after the company fell short of revenue estimates and cut its 2022 profit view on economic headwinds, although it delivered stronger-than-expected quarterly results.

* General Electric reported third-quarter profit that fell below expectations while revenue beat. Its free cash flow topped $1 billion to beat forecasts by a wide margin. Shares were down 1.9%.

* Adidas AG XE:ADS ADDYY on Tuesday became the latest company to cut ties with the rapper Kanye West over anti-Semitic comments he's made on social media. Adidas said it would terminate its relationship with West, who is now called Ye, immediately. American depositary receipts for Adidas fell 4.1%.

* Canopy Growth Corp.'s CA:WEED U.S.-listed shares CGC rose 25% after the Canadian cannabis company announced a plan to consolidate its U.S. cannabis assets into a new holding company called Canopy USA.

* Shares of aircraft-maker Boeing Co. BA were up 2.5%, building on a nine-day gain the Dow component that had seen it rise 10.3%, according to Dow Jones Market Data.

Dow hits 6-week high as stocks rally amid earnings deluge while Treasury yields retreat
